Mineralogy, ins this country, IS IN s infancy the
cultivation of it, therefore, opens wide door to
useful discovery, as well as to individual wealth.
Of eight or nine hundred minerals described IN our

embracing such great variety OF soil and chmate,

GEOLOGY, which may be considered as branch
ofMneralogy, points out the nature, structure and
relative position of the different strata that compose
the crust of the EARTH Until late years TINS science
has been pursued as mere speculation and wri-
ters have heaped together mass OF Materials de-
serving no better name than lumber, but which has
been digni6ed with the title OF "Iheory OF the
Earth" The world has seen fifty Of these theories,
in little more than twice that number OF years and
their authors, to adopt the language Of late writer
on this subject have not scrupled to call IN the
aid of analogy and thus by hypothesis after hypoth


esis they analyse and recompound the vast globe OF
the GARTH as lift were piece OF metal which Inc
Chemist could fuse in his crucible !"


| 1t is only by reasoning from whatwe kao7e-from
facts and observations that are enabled TO form
rational system--to reason correctly we must make
effects the guiding thread to their causes but When
it is considered that all the facts known respecting
the earth are but few-that we have not penetrated
beyond the ace,-hat we have not, IN short, ex-
amined one ten thousandth part OF the globe--We
have right to conclude, that any one who should pre-


tend to have formed true theory otthe earth from
such slender data can have no better claim 10 our
regard than the empyrc who should undertake 10


illustrate the structure and functions OF the internal


parts of the body, by mere inspection OF the SKIN
Yet, the little we do see of the earth proves to
us that great revolutions have taken place. eilnd
evidences of general deluge-that the great deePs,
as we'll as the great heights have been, IN the IAN
los''-" without form and void''-has preceded the

encompass the earth, though but as grain OF sand


in the universe, it escapes our feeble grasp, and we


are reminded that 9. life is short science long, OPP


portunites of knowledge and experiments alacious'
, and reasoning difficult" Even effects themselves


are not always in proportion to their causes as 1ey


appear to as and whilst we are considering part


of what we see as the result OF terrible and unver-

geology practical science, it is capable OF being
by piled to highly useful purpose. 1t is ny pursuh

md the discovery of coal and many of the metals Il
h nature in the location and deposition OF these su

re sant relation to exist between substances ON the


face of the earth. or within our immediate opserv

As ignorance of these geological facts has often give

m inc for minerals. where il was impossible that the

our pleasures, but interests in the study OF HI

Science, By Nm. Gibbons, NJ. D. President.
FELLOW CITIZENS:


In discharge of the duties of my appointment,
proceed to give an imperfect sketch Of some of the
objects embraced by our Association.


Man, destitute of mental cultivation, has been
aptly compared TO block of MARBLE in the state in
which we find it when taken from the quarry. A
good education accomplishes in the one case what
the chisel of skilfu artist performs in the other
and by small acquaintance only with mankind, we
are enabled to perceive the closeness of the ANA
ogy.


In whatever point of view we consider the human
being--whether we regard his present comforts, his
future prospects, the benefits to be derived from his
civil and social relations the exaation of his ma
ture, or his high destiny--we shall find that all is
staked on the Improvement Of his mind.
! In whatever region Of the globe we discover him
whether roaming Indian in the West a wander
ing Arab in the East, shivering at the North, bask
ing in the South or an inhabltant of the favor
ed climes Of Europe--void of intellectual improve
rnent he is still, wherever located, savage crea
| ture surrounded by wants and wretchedness, or
plum sed into excesses IN his pleasures low and
sensual fierce in his desires, cruel in his resent
ments. Destitute, in this state, of capacity for ra-
tona government, he either lives in anarchy, or
crouches to a despot Ignorant or regardless OF
his moral and religious duties, the victim OF impos-
ture, or the slave OF superstition.


But happily for race, there is another side to
this picture, where the barren waste trans
formed into paradise, with the stree of life,o
dfIusing its benecent influence through every COM
partment For man. enlightened by the rays OF
science, and Improved by intellectual exercise dis
plays an almost nexhaustible fund of resources, in
subdung obstacles to supply his wants, and to null
tiply his comforts and his advantages. But 1t is
when he adds VIRTUE to knowledge, that he as
IL of bic caIo harp nre-
sents himself to us a finished character; and it is
, when we view him in this position, that we can
adopt the language of the Psamist :-s' Thou hast
made him little lower than the angels, and hast
crowned him with glory and honour!''


To reach this exalted point on the scale of Great
ed beings ought to be the primary object of each
: individual and this Academy, being organized fol


the purpose of lultivang the NATURAL SCIENCES, as


one of the means OF attaining this elevation cheer
Il fully embrace the present opportunity to inquire
u briefly, how far they may be made subservent te
. the noble design.


The natural sciences include within their exten


sye range vast number and variety of objects
+e eyery thing in short on this globe, and within it


both animate and inanimate. Hence, wherever the


eve turns or the foot treads, subjects intrude upor


us, exciting attention, or inviting our inquiry


In order to distinguish one thing from another, ant
facilitate the acquisition of knowledge, naturalist





~ ~ tenl-to divide sub-divide arrange, and form nom
- enclatures and whatever cavillers may say upo
GO this subject the immense number and variety OF oh


iects, their equally various relations, with their s.


mltudes--all point out the necessity OF systemati


arrangement science destitute of this would be
chaos, without form and void" But whilst &c


yocating the necessity of systems, it ought not to


forgotten that to know the name OF thing merel.


although essential to science, is scarcely, of itsel
Cdi yVo tho Ot animals. plant
- and minerals; we may even acquire several ia
Ps' puanes and have as many names for each article
~ but if we remain ignorant ofthelr natures and use
'I' all our knowledge is little better than learned Ign
e. rance and, although DEPRESSION, may be alo'
ed the remark that present modes OF educatio
~ are too much limited to this kind OF learning, a.


that after having passed through what is dgnhed WI
, the name of finished education if we stop here
we do not observe, read, and Think for ourselve
10 we shall be found almost destitute OF real kno'
-, ledge We have only been putt possession OF Y


tools with which to acquire and IT we do not hand
them they will rust our hands, and our hnsh
'z education will prove but of little benefit, either
go 80 ourselves or the world.
~ ~ The NATURAL SCIENCES, or those embraced
- our institution, arranged under the three gre
w W heads denominaed the ANIMAL, the VEGETABLE, a
I' the MINERAL kingdoms. In the few remarks vino
NM NM am TO make on each of them, shall begin with tn
u.' ' which is the most simple and easy: ascending,
e'- the progress of investigation to that which is mo
- complicated and difficult.


MINrRALoai treats of all the inorganic substanc


found on the surface of the earth, and WlthnIt.
. far as our knowledge extends the number OF slmp


bo,ies arc fe,y but the manner in which the COZ
ay. mounds are formed. and the properties OF the mgr


dients are so multiform, that they produce an ame


infinite number of transformations, all differing elt
or in their external characters orlntern qualitle
= - and which often delight and surprise us with their
Il - nd beautv In these operations the INC

Delivered before The Deiaooare .4cademy Of Natural


Science, By Nm. Gibbons, NJ. D. President.
FEILow-CIrIxENs
TUESDAY,, October so, 1927.

Science, By Nm. Gibbons, NJ. D. President.
FELLOW CITIZENS:


In discharge of the duties of my appointment,
proceed to give an imperfect sketch Of some of the
objects embraced by our Association.


Man, destitute of mental cultivation, has been
aptly compared TO block of MARBLE in the state in
which we find it when taken from the quarry. A
good education accomplishes in the one case what
the chisel of skilfu artist performs in the other
and by small acquaintance only with mankind, we
are enabled to perceive the closeness of the ANA
ogy.


In whatever point of view we consider the human
being--whether we regard his present comforts, his
future prospects, the benefits to be derived from his
civil and social relations the exaation of his ma
ture, or his high destiny--we shall find that all is
staked on the Improvement Of his mind.
! In whatever region Of the globe we discover him
whether roaming Indian in the West a wander
ing Arab in the East, shivering at the North, bask
ing in the South or an inhabltant of the favor
ed climes Of Europe--void of intellectual improve
rnent he is still, wherever located, savage crea
| ture surrounded by wants and wretchedness, or
plum sed into excesses IN his pleasures low and
sensual fierce in his desires, cruel in his resent
ments. Destitute, in this state, of capacity for ra-
tona government, he either lives in anarchy, or
crouches to a despot Ignorant or regardless OF
his moral and religious duties, the victim OF impos-
ture, or the slave OF superstition.


But happily for race, there is another side to
this picture, where the barren waste trans
formed into paradise, with the stree of life,o
dfIusing its benecent influence through every COM
partment For man. enlightened by the rays OF
science, and Improved by intellectual exercise dis
plays an almost nexhaustible fund of resources, in
subdung obstacles to supply his wants, and to null
tiply his comforts and his advantages. But 1t is
when he adds VIRTUE to knowledge, that he as
IL of bic caIo harp nre-
sents himself to us a finished character; and it is
, when we view him in this position, that we can
adopt the language of the Psamist :-s' Thou hast
made him little lower than the angels, and hast
crowned him with glory and honour!''


To reach this exalted point on the scale of Great
ed beings ought to be the primary object of each
: individual and this Academy, being organized fol


the purpose of lultivang the NATURAL SCIENCES, as


one of the means OF attaining this elevation cheer
Il fully embrace the present opportunity to inquire
u briefly, how far they may be made subservent te
. the noble design.


The natural sciences include within their exten


sye range vast number and variety of objects
+e eyery thing in short on this globe, and within it


both animate and inanimate. Hence, wherever the


eve turns or the foot treads, subjects intrude upor


us, exciting attention, or inviting our inquiry


In order to distinguish one thing from another, ant
facilitate the acquisition of knowledge, naturalist





~ ~ tenl-to divide sub-divide arrange, and form nom
- enclatures and whatever cavillers may say upo
GO this subject the immense number and variety OF oh


iects, their equally various relations, with their s.


mltudes--all point out the necessity OF systemati


arrangement science destitute of this would be
chaos, without form and void" But whilst &c


yocating the necessity of systems, it ought not to


forgotten that to know the name OF thing merel.


although essential to science, is scarcely, of itsel

'I' all our knowledge is little better than learned Ign
e. rance and, although DEPRESSION, may be alo'
ed the remark that present modes OF educatio
~ are too much limited to this kind OF learning, a.


that after having passed through what is dgnhed WI
, the name of finished education if we stop here
we do not observe, read, and Think for ourselve
10 we shall be found almost destitute OF real kno'
-, ledge We have only been putt possession OF Y


tools with which to acquire and IT we do not hand
them they will rust our hands, and our hnsh
'z education will prove but of little benefit, either
go 80 ourselves or the world.

- our institution, arranged under the three gre

u.' ' which is the most simple and easy: ascending,
e'- the progress of investigation to that which is mo
- complicated and difficult.
